ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I would self-describe myself as able to "speak a bit of French" now! Basically-- this course will teach you all the grammar and a good collection of vocabulary, especially vocal needed for travel and everyday affairs. I would describe my skills as highest by far in reading, in which I feel fine reading basically anything, though I probably look up 5-10 words per page, followed by writing, in which I can express most things I want to say in some form without looking things up, and better if I can look up maybe 5-10 words per written page, then speaking, which I can do well slowly but much more basically, followed by listening. Listening to the news, I can make out the sounds well and understand the gist, but would need a lot of backing up and rewatching to understand every single word even on familiar topics. Watching TV or French you tubers is more difficult since they speak casually, but I can typically follow a show's plot with visual indicators, or understand at least 40-50% of spoken language even with some speed.

I started the course knowing no French at all and over the course of just one semester, I feel I have learned an incredible amount. This course and Mme. Sherak are very good at emphasizing not only grammar and writing but also listening, understanding, and speaking.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think one of the main strengths of this course is that the class usually has few students and therefore every student receives a lot of individual attention and care from the professor. The course is set up so that you are immediately immersed in the language and practice all aspects of language learning (speaking and pronunciation, reading, writing and dictation, listening comprehension, etc.) from the very beginning and throughout the entire course. I also love how we did a few things like visit the art gallery and get crepes during some of our class times to practice using French outside the classroom.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. One of the best classes I've taken at Yale. Instruction is great, material moves smoothly and quickly, and class becomes friendly. If you want to learn French take it.
Yes! Great course if you want to learn French. Putting in more will result in getting out more.

If you are set on learning French and want to do so quickly and thoroughly I would very highly recommend this course. Though the course moves fast and requires a lot of dedication, if you stick to it, you will get so much out of it. Every time I think about French, I'm blown away by how much I know from just one semester.
